{"comments": {"id": 27449, "count": 12, "talk_id": 2857}, "threadId": 27449, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2857", "description": "We're so used to narratives out of Africa being about war, poverty and devastation, says TED Fellow Wanuri Kahiu. Where's the fun? Introducing "AfroBubbleGum" -- African art that's vibrant, lighthearted and without a political agenda. Rethink the value of all that is unserious as Kahiu explains why we need art that captures the full range of human experiences to tell the stories of Africa.", "event": "TED2017", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Wanuri Kahiu: Fun, fierce and fantastical African art", "slug": "wanuri_kahiu_fun_fierce_and_fantastical_african_art", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3451", "slug": "wanuri_kahiu", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Wanuri", "lastname": "Kahiu", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Filmmaker, writer", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/bd73c3d00368890f25e92322473ae451d34de801_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Wanuri Kahiu wants to curate, commission and create art that celebrates fun, fierce and frivolous Africa.", "whylisten": "

Born in Nairobi, TED Fellow Wanuri Kahiu is part of the new generation of African filmmakers. Her films have received international acclaim and have been screened in more than 100 film festivals around the world. To date, Kahiu has written and directed six films and is working on her second feature length film.

Kahiu's first feature film, From a Whisper, based on the real events surrounding the 1998 twin bombings of US Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, won Best Narrative Feature in 2010 at the Pan African Film Festival in Los Angeles as well as five awards at the African Movie Academy Award, including Best Director and Best Screenplay.

In 2009 Wanuri produced TV documentary For Our Land about Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Professor Wangari Maathai for MNET, a pan-African cable station. In 2010, her short science fiction Pumzi premiered at Sundance and went on to win best short film at Cannes and the silver at Carthage Film Festival in Tunisia. Pumzi also earned Kahiu the Citta di Venezia 2010 award in Venice, Italy. She is currently in post production on her second feature film, Rafiki, as well as a feature length documentary Ger about UNHCR Goodwill Ambassador Ger Duany.

fun, fierce and frivolous Africa.", "whylisten": "

Born in Nairobi, TED Fellow Wanuri Kahiu is part of the new generation of African filmmakers. Her films have received international acclaim and have been screened in more than 100 film festivals around the world. To date, Kahiu has written and directed six films and is working on her second feature length film.

Kahiu's first feature film, From a Whisper, based on the real events surrounding the 1998 twin bombings of US Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, won Best Narrative Feature in 2010 at the Pan African Film Festival in Los Angeles as well as five awards at the African Movie Academy Award, including Best Director and Best Screenplay.

In 2009 Wanuri produced TV documentary For Our Land about Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Professor Wangari Maathai for MNET, a pan-African cable station. In 2010, her short science fiction Pumzi premiered at Sundance and went on to win best short film at Cannes and the silver at Carthage Film Festival in Tunisia. Pumzi also earned Kahiu the Citta di Venezia 2010 award in Venice, Italy. She is currently in post production on her second feature film, Rafiki, as well as a feature length documentary Ger about UNHCR Goodwill Ambassador Ger Duany.

author: Wanuri_Kahiu;
title: Fun, fierce and fantastical African art

aws-transcripts.transcript: So my mother is a pediatrician, and when I was young, she tell the craziest stories that combined science with her overactive imagination. One of the stories you told was that if you eat a lot of salt, all the blood rushes up your legs through your body and shoots at the top of your head, killing you instantly.
